[SEP] But he is best known for stressing the symbolic nature of make-believe. [SEP] Pretending, Piaget pointed out, is a vital means of mentally representing the world that, along with gestures, language, and drawings, develops rapidly in early childhood. [SEP] Through it, children practice and strengthen their capacity to represent their experiences.3 [SEP] For example, when Sophie pretended to put the animals to bed and used a TinkerToy to stand for a lollipop, she represented in her mind what formerly she could experience only directly—by

[SEP] Nevertheless, Piaget was convinced that by itself, make-believe play does little to advance children’s development. [SEP] The small grove in front of the square has a number of trees dedicated by personalities who have visited here, including Indira Gandhi. [SEP] The roller-coaster dips and crests of the city’s hills, breaking up the monotony of the standard grid system of streets, reach a crazy climax on Lombard Street between Hyde and Leavenworth. [SEP] After you’ve negotiated all eight hairpin bends lined with gardens of hydrangeas, you’re not
column3: to quibble about the claim that it’s the “crookedest street in the world.” [SEP] Two blocks south is Filbert Street, boasting the steepest slope — a stomach-churning 31.5 percent gradient, with no bends. [SEP] It is worth climbing to the top of Telegraph Hill for the view of the bay from the top of Coit Tower, built in 1934 to honor the city’s fire department. [SEP] One of San Francisco’s many landmarks, its shape is not meant to resemble the nozzle of a fire hose, as is so often reported. [SEP] Inside you will find Socialist Realist murals depicting “Life in California, 1934.” [SEP] Take a look at the cottages and gardens around the Greenwich Steps, clinging to the steep slope overlooking the bay — this is one of the city’s most desirable addresses.

[SEP] From the days when the poet Lawrence Ferlinghetti gathered fellow Beats around his City Lights Bookstore during the 1950s, North Beach has been a hangout for the bohemian literary crowd. column3: strong today. [SEP] Once you’ve bought your copy of On the Road, cross Jack Kerouac Street and settle down with your purchase over a drink at Vesuvio’s, another famous literary hangout. [SEP] Or if it’s a sunny day, buy a sandwich from a delicatessen and enjoy a picnic on Washington Square, a splash of green overlooked by the white spires of the Church of Saints Peter and Paul, where Marilyn Monroe and Joe DiMaggio were married in 1954.

[SEP] Beside the Plaza is Monterey’s Fisherman’s Wharf. [SEP] Like San Francisco’s, it is a collection of souvenir shops and restaurants on the dock, offering a great view across the boats in the marina. [SEP] The fish on sale is most definitely fresh, but alas, no longer abundant enough to keep Cannery Row
column3: as more than a weather-beaten curiosity. [SEP] The famous sardine fisheries finally closed down in the 1940s as a result of over-fishing, but the waterfront district of timbered canneries, immortalized by the novelist John Steinbeck as “a poem, a stink, a grating noise, a quality of light, a tone, a habit, a nostalgia,” has found a new lease on life today as a tourist attraction with souvenir shops, delightful cozy boutiques, and artists’ studios. [SEP] One old cannery building has been splendidly converted to the Monterey Bay Aquarium, one of the premier aquariums in the world as well as an educational showcase for the unique underwater environment of Monterey Bay. [SEP] The boom years of the 1920s saw the growth of a “branch-plant economy;” with American automobile, rubber, chemical, and clothing factories springing up around the Great Lakes at Hamilton, Oshawa, Windsor, and Montréal. [SEP] The boom in American popular culture inundated Canada with radio, movies, and mass-market magazines. [SEP] Québec, in particular, tried to resist the invasion, even

[SEP] Even the drought in 1929 did not ease matters, and ten more years of bad harvests meant they would not recoup their losses. [SEP] Other sectors of the economy — timber, fisheries, mining, and construction — ground to a halt as production outstripped demand. [SEP] From the Yukon, further migrations took them north to the High Arctic, south around Hudson Bay to Manitoba, east to Greenland, and down the Labrador coast to Newfoundland. [SEP] For the West Coast peoples, as the song says, the living was easy. [SEP] The fish were indeed jumping; bountiful salmon were barbecued in the summertime, smoked for the winter. [SEP] Prehistoric techniques for fishing and trapping have continued right into modern times, though bone has been replaced by steel in the weapons. [SEP] Prairie Indians hunted buffalo by forcing the herds onto marshland, snowbanks, thin ice, or over cliffs — one of these nasty surprises being known to this day as the Head-Smashed-In buffalo jump, near Fort MacLeod, Alberta. [SEP] Already in 3000 b.c. these people were drying and smoking strips of meat — modern beef jerky. [SEP] In Ontario and Québec, where encroaching forests gradually dispersed the herds of caribou, the Iroquois ousted the Algonquin and settled down to cultivate maize, beans, and squash, living in rectangular, multifamily longhouses. column1: You might face severe punishment from those very proud Torontonians if you don’t begin your waterfront tour with a trip up the CN Tower. [SEP] This handsome, outsize TV antenna makes up for its unimaginative name (from its builder, the Canadian National railway and telecommunications company) with all the fanciful interpretations of its shape: jousting lance, hypodermic needle, serpent frozen rigid while swallowing a football. [SEP] At 605 m (1,815 ft), it is currently the world’s highest freestanding structure, 19 m (56 ft) more than a similar monster in Moscow. [SEP] A plexiglass elevator whizzes you up the outside of the tower to two observation decks in the Skypod. [SEP] The ride is free for those
column3: to the revolving restaurant or nightclub (which also rank as the world’s highest, if you don’t count a couple in the Rockies, Alps, and Himalayas). [SEP] The view at the top reveals a whole history of Toronto in the contrast between the glass-and-steel skyscraper canyons of the financial district, the geometric dome and cantilevered structures of the Ontario Place leisure complex, and the old-fashioned gabled houses of the neighborhoods. [SEP] Take a second elevator to the Space Deck, to get the full sweep of Lake Ontario’s so-called “Golden Horseshoe.” [SEP] Including Toronto, this dense urban belt from Oshawa in the east to Hamilton and St. Catharines in the west houses half the total population of the province. [SEP] The marvelously entertaining Ontario Science Centre stands 11 km (6 miles) northeast of the city center (770 Don Mills Rd.). [SEP] Here, adults and children are expected to participate, and they do so enthusiastically in what turns into a sophisticated push-button play center, focused as much on the future as the past and present —  proving that science can be fun.

column1: Fiestas The Spanish colonists carried on the traditions of their mother country, and to this day there are yearly fiestas in most major towns. [SEP] Many mark Saint’s days or founding days, and the whole population will dress up and enjoy lots of singing and dancing. [SEP] Most have a religious procession to start the proceedings. [SEP] The major fiestas are listed in the Calendar of Events (see page 92), but ask the tourist information office about what’s
column3: on during your stay. [SEP] The city of Mérida seems to be in the throes of a constant fiesta, hosting live cultural shows at sites around the downtown area. [SEP] Here you will find the most authentic cultural displays in the region. [SEP] The program changes nightly from ballet to traditional Yucatecan folk music and dances, and all the performances are free. [SEP] There are special performances on the famed Mérida Domingos (Mérida Sundays), lasting all day but for a short break in the heat of the afternoon, and coinciding with a huge market. [SEP] On Sunday evenings Mexican families take to the streets to meet friends and family, dance, and generally have a good time.

[SEP] Follow the gulf south to Istro where there are a cluster of hotels, and then on along the coastal plain to one of the major ancient sites in the east — Gourniá, 18 km (11 miles) south of Ágios Nikólaos. [SEP] Myriad stone walls — foundations for multi-storied homes — linked by cobbled streets blanket the hillside site of Gourniá. [SEP] Here more than any other site it is possible to envision ordinary Minoans
column3: about their business. [SEP] You’ll be able to explore the marketplace and workshops of the artisans. [SEP] The palace sat at the top of the hill, its west court housing sacrificial slab and magazines for storage of ritual liquids and libations as seen in other Minoan palaces. [SEP] Gourniá was a large city, stretching down to the coast where it had an important port. [SEP] Much remains to be discovered under the low scrub and rocks though there seems little intent to do so. [SEP] The best overview of Gourniá — excavated by American Harriet Boyd Hawkes in the early 1900s — is from the main road as it rises beyond the archaeological site.

column1: Live Music Performances Cubans crave live music, and — with the surge in international popularity of traditional Cuban music — so do most visitors to Cuba. [SEP] You certainly won’t have to go out of your way to hear music performances. [SEP] Roving groups of musicians can be found playing everywhere from airports to restaurants. [SEP] Merely wandering the streets of Havana, Santiago, or Trinidad, you’re likely to stumble across a party with a live band, or even a back alley where some impromptu jamming is

[SEP] All the styles of Cuba’s delectable traditional music �� habaneras, son, boleros, guarachas, guajiras, and more — can be heard in every town’s casa de la trova, usually a fine old building on or near the main square. [SEP] Performances are amateur and professional, take place afternoons and evenings, and are free or have a minimal cover charge (US$1–$2). [SEP] However, locals also claim that Columbus first landed at this spot (rather than near Gibara, north and west of here, as most historians believe). [SEP] They insist that Columbus planted the Cruz de la Parra (Cross of the Vine) in the soil on his arrival. [SEP] The cross is on display in Nuestra Señora de la Asunción, the church on Plaza Independencia. [SEP] (Whatever the truth of the matter, carbon dating has established that the cross is more than 500 years old.) [SEP] Baracoa, though, has so much

column1: Modern Times When India became independent in 1947, pressure for change mounted within Nepal. [SEP] In 1950, King Tribhuvan pretended he was
column3: on a shooting picnic and managed to escape to India. [SEP] An uprising spread against the Ranas, and Prime Minister Mohan Shumshere Rana resigned in 1951. [SEP] King Tribhuvan returned, a first constitution for the monarchy was installed, and some foreigners were allowed into Nepal. [SEP] Two years later, Mount Everest was conquered. [SEP] King Mahendra acceded to the throne on the death of his father Tribhuvan in 1955. [SEP] After an experiment with elections and parliamentary democracy, King Mahendra abolished the constitution in 1962 and instituted the system of “panchayat democracy.” [SEP] Road-building and airport construction progressed during his reign.

column1: Trekking Tips Good hiking boots are the most important equipment for trekkers. [SEP] Although some people trek in running shoes and even flip-flops (and Nepali porters go barefoot), it is advisable to wear sturdy hiking boots with lug soles and especially solid ankle support. [SEP] A second pair of athletic shoes or river sandals can be packed for changing into at day’s end. [SEP] A light pair of sock liners covered by heavier woolen socks or a pair of high-tech sweat-wicking sports socks make for comfort
column3: up- and downhill. [SEP] Be sure to have a roll of moleskin or adhesive plaster to put on your heels or other friction spots before blisters form, and to make a cushioned pad around any blister. [SEP] Tight pants, such as blue jeans, can make for very uncomfortable climbing. [SEP] Looser pants, shorts, or, for women, a calf-length loose skirt (such skirts are widely sold in Kathmandu and Pokhara) are recommended. [SEP] You’ll also need extra socks (keep a dry pair separate for putting on at the end of the day), a couple of changes of pants and shirts, a wool sweater or synthetic fleece jacket, and a down jacket. [SEP] Prince Henry retired to what was known as the “end-of-the-world,” the Sagres peninsula in the Algarve (see page 101). [SEP] There he established a school of navigation that attracted astronomers, cartographers, and other leading scientists of the day. [SEP] Henry established expeditions that ultimately succeeded in redefining Europeans’ very understanding of the world. [SEP] During Henry’s lifetime, Portuguese caravels sailed far beyond the westernmost point of Africa. [SEP] With the colonization of Madeira and the Azores, the foundations were laid for the future Portuguese empire. [SEP] The Portuguese also sailed down the west coast of Africa,
column3: beyond Cape Bojador in 1434, a feat theretofore considered to be impossible. [SEP] Henry died in 1460, but Portugal’s discovery voyages continued. [SEP] The king who ruled over the golden age of exploration — and exploitation — was Manuel I “The Fortunate,” who reigned from 1495–1521. [SEP] The many important discoveries that were made during his reign would assure his position as Europe’s richest ruler: He could well afford to erect monuments as elegant as the Tower of Belém and as impressive as the Jerónimos Monastery in Lisbon.

column1: Music Music is the ingredient that keeps this island moving, and, whatever their age, Puerto Ricans cannot help but dance to any beat they hear. [SEP] The popular rhythms are a unique mixture of Spanish and African influences, though the instruments traditionally used have antecedents
column3: back further than the Spanish colonial and African slave imports. [SEP] The güiro, a percussion instrument made of a notched dried gourd, was developed by the Taíno Indians. [SEP] To this the Spanish added several types of guitars, with the ten-stringed cuatro being the most famous — it is the national instrument of Puerto Rico. [SEP] African slaves brought with them the wherewithal to produce tambours, wood covered in animal skin to create drums, and maracas, dried gourds filled with seeds. [SEP] These instruments played together form the basic “orchestra” for several popular musical genres. [SEP] There’s much of architectural interest around the pretty promenades and grand houses.
